content: Energy and Water Development funding for FY2010 was provided in H.R. 3183, which became P.L. 111-85 when signed by President Obama on October 28, 2009, totaling $33.5 billion. The American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (P.L. 111-5) also allocated $44.3 billion for programs in the Corps of Engineers, the Bureau of Reclamation, and the Department of Energy. President Obama's proposed FY2011 budget for Energy and Water Development programs was $35.3 billion. On July 15, 2010, the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Energy and Water Development approved a bill for funding. The House Appropriations Subcommittee on Energy and Water Development approved a bill to fund programs at $34.7 billion, while the Senate approved a bill with $35.0 billion. A continuing resolution was passed to fund government programs at the FY2010 level until March 4, 2011. The House and Senate approved bills to fund Energy and Water Development programs at different levels. A continuing resolution extended funding through March 4, 2011, with amendments made to reduce funding levels for certain programs. H.R. 1 was introduced to continue funding for the rest of FY2011 at FY2010 levels, with exceptions for reduced funding. The House passed H.R. 1, and the Senate offered a substitute amendment to continue funding with fewer restrictions. The Senate rejected both the House-passed version of H.R. 1 and the S.Amdt. 149, leading to the introduction of H.R. 1473, which was passed by both chambers and signed into law. This bill funded Energy and Water Development programs at approximately $32.2 billion.
